posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
I am very happy to introduce the KITCHEN SINK, a replacement for the outgoing Swyft RoboRIO JST adapter , and also a culmination of every good (and possibly bad) idea I’ve ever had for a RoboRIO expansion board.

Background:

The moment I laid eyes on the RoboRIO for the first time in 2015, I had lots of ideas. The MXP port opened up all sorts of opportunities that the cRio would have made horribly inconvenient.

I remember my very first thought being “man, it’d be cool if you could plug an Arduino in there.” My second thought was “man, I wish I could plug LEDs in there.”

There were also some things I didn’t like about the RoboRIO. Those 0.1" header pins are great for hobby projects, but they just don’t hold very firmly inside an FRC robot. Also, the RoboRIO lacks ports for a variety of COTS sensors that see common use, like beam break sensors.

Another thing that has always bothered me with FRC electrical parts, RoboRIO included, is the lack of thought that goes into cable management. The RoboRIO has mounting screw holes, so it gets one part of the equation right. But, for all the cables coming out of it, you’d think they’d give you something to tie those down with.

Introducing the Kitchen Sink:

So, with all of that in mind, I designed a couple of RoboRIO expansion boards where I try to manifest all of these ideas.

Here’s the first one, the true Kitchen Sink:

Kitchen Sink board render. 1723×914 128 KB

Kitchen Sink board render. 1723×914 128 KB

Kitchen Sink board render. 1723×914 128 KB

This board features absolutely everything I could cram on top of a RoboRIO. Naturally, it has all 32 “standard” RoboRIO IO ports. That’s all 10 DIOs, all 10 PWMs, all 4 analog inputs, all 4 relay outputs, I2C, SPI, RS-232, and RSL . In addition, it has…

5 additional PWM /DIO ports from the MXP port.

3 additional analog inputs from the MXP port.

1 analog output from the MXP port.

1 additional SPI port from MXP.

1 TTL UART port from MXP.

2 additional I2C ports from MXP.

2 ports specially designed to connect to LIDAR Lite V3 sensors in PWM mode.

2 ports specially designed to connect to COTS open-collector beam break sensors, like OBP903.

1 indicator LED wired into a DIO on the MXP port.

MVDD SEL header, which allows you to change the supply voltage supplied on MXP DIO/AIN ports between 3.3 and 5V.

7 convenient cable tie points.

Mount point for an Arduino Nano Every, which then adds the following features: SPI connection (enabled via Rio CS1) between the Rio’s SPI port and the Arduino. 3 PWM -capable arduino DIOs. 4 Arduino analog inputs which can also be used as DIOs. 2 more PWM -capable arduino DIOs wired into Wago 250 connectors, capable of delivering adequate current to drive LED strips. Another indicator LED.

SPI connection (enabled via Rio CS1) between the Rio’s SPI port and the Arduino.

3 PWM -capable arduino DIOs.

4 Arduino analog inputs which can also be used as DIOs.

2 more PWM -capable arduino DIOs wired into Wago 250 connectors, capable of delivering adequate current to drive LED strips.

Another indicator LED.

Introducing the Little Sink:

So, some might argue that the Kitchen Sink might be slightly overkill. So, I whipped up another board called “Little Sink:”

Little Sink board render. 1723×914 114 KB

Little Sink board render. 1723×914 114 KB

Little Sink board render. 1723×914 114 KB

Little Sink drops the Arduino and COTS sensor-specific stuff. Instead, it’s basically just one of those Swyft JST boards except it also breaks out the entire MXP port.

I’m hoping to get some feedback about this concept in general.

What do/don’t you like about each design?

Is this something your team would want?

What would you want on your own personal “Kitchen Sink” board?

Please note that this is something I’m doing as a side project, and it’s not directly associated with 1732.

link_counts.title: Never Hot Glue Your RIO Again (Almost) - 3DP roboRIO Molex Adapters
Swyft RoboRIO JST Breakout not restocking?

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: Do you have a schematic of the Kitchen Sink to show inspectors to prove it complies with R713?

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
Yes, the schematic should demonstrate compliance with R713 trivially.

Obviously you definitely can’t connect a motor/actuator to the Arduino. Those ports are intentionally placed in a different spot on the board to help clearly distinguish them.

posts.name: Steve Tarr
posts.cooked:
Team 1425 has been using a similar board that I designed a few years ago.  The biggest difference is that we decided to use Euro-block headers rather than JST so that we could use screw- or pressure- connect plugs rather than having to splice or terminate JST.  The Euroblock screw terminals are convenient for both initial assembly and field replacement and have been solidly reliable for us.

Our design is freely available on our Wiki page, or you can send a PM requesting the design files.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
Interesting, I’ll have to take a peek at that. The only real downside to JSTs is the fiddly crimping process - screws would make life a lot easier.

Makes me wonder if there’s another, smaller connector that has euroblock’s convenience and good holding strength.

posts.name: Ryan Reed
posts.cooked:
Wago 250 series (used on the PDH for the fused ports) is available in 2.54mm (0.1") pitch. Availability looks pretty bad though.

Edit: Now that so many teams have Molex SL crimpers that would be a useful change. Even without the right tool, Molex SL is easier to crimp than JST XH and has a more robust retention mechanism.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked: Fair point. Teams like 1732 invested into Swyft’s JST system pretty readily, and I think we’re inclined to stick with the connector we already have a million of. There’s a strong case for Molex SL support. Perhaps two board variants for the two connector types?

posts.name: Ryan Reed
posts.cooked:
Makes sense to keep JST as the primary option then.

If you set up the components right I think it should be relatively simple to create a Molex SL version by just substituting the component in your tool of choice. My experience with that is pretty limited though, I don’t touch Altium that much as a Mechanical Engineer.

Even just an option without the JST XH connectors would be helpful, for the 3 pin headers its only 0.04mm off, well within the clearance of the holes.
